ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: General understanding of urban education, urban housing, and racial policies.
I gained much greater knowledge of housing and education inequities as well as a stronger understanding of structural racism.
The course afforded the academic perspective I had sought out in initially registering for the course.

gained knowledge about the deep history of residential and educational segregation, gained knowledge about the effects of policies and government decisions, the extent to which segregation and racial discriminatory practices still exist
Ethnographic research

This class offered incredible new insights into how systems of housing and education work within the United States and how they structure and are structured by race and racism. The readings in this class are fantastic and offer a dense amount of new information and perspectives.
I learned much more about the non-economic variables at play in education inequality.

I learned so much about the racial, social, and economic processes that were used to create today's housing and education sectors. This class helped me to think more critically about urban planning and education policy in my state and beyond.
Reading and writing quickly and intentionally
I learned about the basic history of educational and housing policy in America, and particularly in urban cities.

I learned about the interconnectedness between housing policies and schooling, and I learned about how the government and private real estate companies lead to systemic racisms that continues to this day.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength of this class is that both the teacher and the material itself were very engaging, which made the class very interesting and enjoyable. A weakness of the class is that the assessment instructions were often vague, so I didn't feel very clear about what I was supposed to be doing. A way to improve this class would be to provide greater direction in the essays.
Strengths lie in the content; weaknesses in the brevity of the summer session in which it is offered.

strengths: the readings were very insightful and useful in understanding the history of segregation in America
weaknesses: classes were largely lecture based, would have liked more discussion time

The strengths of this class are its heavy discussion focus, the wonderfully curated reading list, and the faculty. Professor Barnes and Gabrielle created an amazing class environment for considering and pondering the material, and their assignments were perfect for synthesizing and developing new opinions. I absolutely adored Professor Barnes and Gabrielle and am so very appreciative of them.

Professor Barnes was fantastic.

I would like to see more quantitative studies to support the qualitative works.
The readings were fantastic, but I wish we had some shorter readings in order to cover more material. Incorporating podcast and short films could also help enrich the readings.

Only weakness is that it seemed like certain weeks were about education and others about housing. Sometimes it was hard to piece these complicated policies together.  Also the grades did not come back fast enough - so it was hard to improve our work week to week.

Strengths include the discussion nature of the course, and how students were able to freely discuss their thoughts on the assigned readings. I wished there was a clearer transition/link between education and housing policy that was mentioned in readings. There were also at times lulls in discussion, and so during those moments, guiding questions would be helpful to facilitate further conversation. Another improvement may be including a list of questions or topics for students to think about before the assigned readings, so they come to class prepared with engaging, critical thoughts.

The strengths of this course were that it was very interactive and thought-provoking. The weaknesses were that the lecture portion took up a bit too much of class time. It would be nice to have these parts recorded to watch beforehand in the future.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think this class does a great job really exploring the ways in which African Americans have been disadvantaged through government policy.
I would absolutely recommend the course, though advise as with any course the amount of time one can dedicate to the course and its material will relate to the experience with it.
Yes, if you are interested in understanding why racial segregation still exists in the neighborhoods and schools in America, then this class is great
Yes, the course allows you to explore and focus on whatever you are passionate about!
Absolutely! This class is by far one of my favorites I have taken at Yale. The topic matter is necessary and how Professor Barnes curates the readings and leads discussion makes it truly excellent.
Absolutely; understanding educational inequalities is critical for all in my opinion.
Yes! Dr. Barnes and Gabrielle are great, and the class is extremely important and interesting.
Yes, anyone going into education should have a grasp of the content covered in this class

Yes, definitely -- this was a different from what I normally take as a CS major, but the weekly readings were very interesting, as are the reading responses that are graded pretty generously. Also, it puts into perspective the education I received growing up, and how different it is from one of my peers.
Yes because you will learn about the historical background of why inequality and systemic racism continues to exist in the United States.
